author: Sara Swann
title: Instagram posts - No, viral footage doesnâ€™t show explosives disguised as food cans in Gaza
text: Get PolitiFact in your inbox. No, viral footage doesnâ€™t show explosives disguised as food cans in Gaza If Your Time is short - Social media posts claim footage from Gaza shows explosives disguised as food cans, but there are no visible labels or pictures on the metal cylinders to suggest they contain food. - Experts on military strategy and the Middle East said the metal cylinders seen in photos and videos online are likely containers for M603 fuzes, which are designed to detonate landmines. Footage shows one of the cans is labeled "fuze mine." - The fuzes are not designed to explode if a person opens the container. It requires 140 to 750 pounds of force to ignite the fuze and trigger an explosion. - Learn more about PolitiFactâ€™s [fact-checking process and rating system](https://www.politifact.com/article/2018/feb/12/principles-truth-o-meter-politifacts-methodology-i/). Social media users are claiming the Israeli military has booby-trapped food cans in Gaza, where, by the United Nationsâ€™ [count,](https://twitter.com/UNRWA/status/1749708634743841023) more than 570,000 Gazans face "catastrophic hunger" amid the Israel-Hamas war. A Jan. 24 [Instagram post](https://www.instagram.com/p/C2fnDvLufbn/) shared a photo of about a dozen metal cylinders and claimed the Israeli military left "these detonators that resemble food cans" at schools in Khan Younis, a city in southern Gaza. "Thinking they were food, displaced families opened the cans. As soon as they did, they exploded and killed them instantly," the post said. The Instagram postâ€™s caption claimed that Israeli forces were "taking advantage of the desperate situation in Gaza." This post was flagged as part of Metaâ€™s efforts to combat false news and misinformation on its News Feed. (Read more about our [partnership with Meta](https://www.facebook.com/help/1952307158131536?helpref=related), which owns Facebook and Instagram.) (Screengrab from Instagram) [Multiple](https://twitter.com/hamasoki/status/1749726473492328746) [X posts](https://twitter.com/BZKanging/status/1750014054523974084) [also](https://twitter.com/afshinrattansi/status/1750082778018857384) [shared](https://twitter.com/l_d70/status/1750061545822748941) footage of the cans and similarly claimed they were concealed munitions. But these social media posts are misleading. Although there has been [significant](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/dozens-deaths-reported-khan-younis-israel-deepens-ground-offensive-wes-rcna135070) [news](https://www.npr.org/2024/01/26/1227074703/survivors-recount-attack-un-facility) [coverage](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-68006607) of Israelâ€™s recent attacks on Khan Younis, we found no reports about Israel using explosives disguised as food cans in Gaza. Experts on military strategy and the Middle East reviewed the footage and told PolitiFact the munition is likely the American-made [M603 fuze](https://cat-uxo.com/explosive-hazards/fuzes/m603-fuze), which is designed to detonate landmines. Some [pro-Palestinian](https://twitter.com/Timesofgaza/status/1749959211096629512) [news](https://twitter.com/QudsNen/status/1749715184858358160) [outlets](https://www.middleeastmonitor.com/20240123-explosive-food-cans-left-behind-for-gazas-civilians-by-israeli-forces/) shared the video thatâ€™s been circulating social media, but they provided no additional information to substantiate the claim. The Middle East Monitor, which shared the viral video, [used](https://www.instagram.com/middleeastmonitor/p/C2c6Lb2Juan/) English subtitles to accompany the Arabic-speaking man in the video. The man claims the metal devices are "canned meat â€¦ found to contain a hidden danger" that "detonate instantly" if opened. (We were not able to independently verify the translation.) Featured Fact-check A [longer version of the video](https://twitter.com/EyeonPalestine/status/1749758873081147567) shows at least one of the cans is labeled "fuze mine." There are no visible labels or pictures on the cans that suggest they contain food. At one point in the video, the man holds up a fuze thatâ€™s been removed from its container. Diagrams of the fuze and its container [show](https://operatormanuals.tpub.com/TM-9-1345-203-12/TM-9-1345-203-120088.htm) the "keyway," or opening mechanism, is on the canâ€™s bottom. In the video, most of the cans have been turned upside-down to make it look as if the keyway is on top. The fuze container is not designed to explode upon opening. Instructions under the diagrams say to open the container and remove the fuze to attach it to a landmine. This fuze is activated when a large amount of force is applied, driving the firing pin into the detonator and causing the landmine to explode, experts said. The metal cylinder acts as a container for the fuze. The M603 fuze alone requires at least 140 pounds to activate, according to [Collective Awareness to Unexploded Ordnance](https://cat-uxo.com/explosive-hazards/fuzes/m603-fuze), an explosive hazards database. When attached to a landmine, it could take as much as 750 pounds of force to trigger an explosion. Because so much weight and pressure are required to ignite the fuze and detonate an explosive, itâ€™s "highly unlikely anyone was harmed or killed by opening up the container that holds this fuze," retired U.S. Army Lt. General Mark Schwartz told PolitiFact. "All the fuzes also have a safety clip on them. I doubt that anyone was deliberately targeted with these fuzes," said Schwartz, who is also a senior fellow at Rand Corp., a nonpartisan research organization. Itâ€™s possible the fuzes are being used for purposes beyond their original design, said Farzin Nadimi, a senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, a Washington, D.C.-based think tank. One such use could be booby-trapping buildings, which is common in urban warfare, he added. But Nadimi said he is "a little skeptical" that opening the cans causes deadly explosions given how these fuzes are typically activated. We rate the claim that a photo shows explosives disguised as food cans False. Our Sources [Instagram post](https://www.instagram.com/p/C2fnDvLufbn/) ( [archived](https://ghostarchive.org/iarchive/instagram/rosypirani/3287518033638717159)), Jan. 24, 2024 Email interview with retired U.S. Army Lt. General Mark Schwartz, senior fellow at Rand Corp., Jan. 30, 2024 Email interview with Farzin Nadimi, a senior fellow at the Washington Institute for Near East Policy, Jan. 31, 2024 United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Palestine Refugees in the Near East, [X post](https://twitter.com/UNRWA/status/1749708634743841023), Jan. 23, 2024 Times of Gaza, [X post](https://twitter.com/Timesofgaza/status/1749959211096629512) ( [archived](https://archive.is/tZDk7)), Jan. 23, 2024 Quds News Network, [X post](https://twitter.com/QudsNen/status/1749715184858358160) ( [archived](https://archive.is/fEGMK)), Jan. 23, 2024 The Middle East Monitor, [Instagram post](https://www.instagram.com/middleeastmonitor/p/C2c6Lb2Juan/), Jan. 23, 2024 [X post](https://twitter.com/hamasoki/status/1749726473492328746), Jan. 23, 2024 [X post](https://twitter.com/BZKanging/status/1750014054523974084), Jan. 23, 2024 [X post](https://twitter.com/EyeonPalestine/status/1749758873081147567), Jan. 23, 2024 [X post](https://twitter.com/afshinrattansi/status/1750082778018857384), Jan. 24, 2024 [X post](https://twitter.com/l_d70/status/1750061545822748941), Jan. 24, 2024 NBC News, " [Dozens of deaths reported in Khan Younis as Israel deepens its ground offensive 'to the west'](https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/dozens-deaths-reported-khan-younis-israel-deepens-ground-offensive-wes-rcna135070)," Jan. 22, 2024 NPR, " ['It felt like my head burst': Survivors recount attack on U.N. facility](https://www.npr.org/2024/01/26/1227074703/survivors-recount-attack-un-facility)," Jan. 26, 2024 BBC, " [At least half of Gaza's buildings damaged or destroyed, new analysis shows](https://www.bbc.com/news/world-middle-east-68006607)," Jan. 30, 2024 Collective Awareness to Unexploded Ordnance, " [M603 fuze](https://cat-uxo.com/explosive-hazards/fuzes/m603-fuze)," accessed Feb. 1, 2024 Operator Manual for [Fuze M603 metal container](https://operatormanuals.tpub.com/TM-9-1345-203-12/TM-9-1345-203-120088.htm), accessed Feb. 1, 2024 France 24, " [No, the Israeli army didn't drop booby-trapped cans of food into Gaza](https://observers.france24.com/en/middle-east/20240130-no-the-israeli-army-didn-t-drop-explosives-made-to-look-like-cans-of-food-into-gaza)," Jan. 30, 2024 Read About Our Process Browse the Truth-O-Meter More by Sara Swann No, viral footage doesnâ€™t show explosives disguised as food cans in Gaza Support independent fact-checking. Become a member! In a world of wild talk and fake news, help us stand up for the facts.

title: Ex-funcionÃ¡rio acusado de aplicar golpe no apresentador Milton Neves Ã© condenado a 5 anos de prisÃ£o e a pagar multa de mais de R$ 800 mil | Sul de Minas | G1
text:
O ex-funcionÃ¡rio que teria aplicado um golpe milionÃ¡rio nas contas das empresas do jornalista e apresentador Milton Neves foi condenado em 1Âª instÃ¢ncia a 5 anos e 2 meses de reclusÃ£o no regime semiaberto, alÃ©m de ter que pagar uma indenizaÃ§Ã£o superior a R$ 860 mil. A defesa dele diz que vai recorrer da decisÃ£o.
ðŸ“² Participe do canal do g1 Sul de Minas no WhatsApp
Apesar do apresentador e do ex-funcionÃ¡rio serem de Muzambinho (MG) , no Sul de Minas, a aÃ§Ã£o corre pelo Tribunal de JustiÃ§a do Estado de SÃ£o Paulo. Evandro CÃ©sar Cesarino Ribeiro foi denunciado em 2021 pelo MinistÃ©rio PÃºblico de SÃ£o Paulo por desvios de dinheiro nas contas das empresas de Milton Neves.
1 de 1 O apresentador Milton Neves, de Muzambinho (MG) â€” Foto: Emilio Botta/ge O apresentador Milton Neves, de Muzambinho (MG) â€” Foto: Emilio Botta/ge
Conforme a sentenÃ§a, no perÃ­odo de 5 de agosto de 2011 a 12 de marÃ§o de 2018, foram efetuadas 250 operaÃ§Ãµes bancÃ¡rias, cujos valores totalizaram R$ 862.883,71 em favor da empresa ECCR ProduÃ§Ã£o de Imagem ComunicaÃ§Ã£o e Fotografia LTDA-ME, de propriedade do ex-funcionÃ¡rios.
TambÃ©m foram emitidas 144 notas fiscais em favor de Moacir Ferreira Lacerda ME, que somam R$ 373.140,94.
A sentenÃ§a tambÃ©m diz que aproveitando-se da condiÃ§Ã£o de diretor financeiro e homem de confianÃ§a de Milton Neves, o ex-funcionÃ¡rio "aproveitou-se do acesso que tinha Ã s contas bancÃ¡rias da empresa para efetuar pagamentos de notas fiscais "frias" emitidas com o intuito de mascarar os desvios que fazia".
Golpe MilionÃ¡rio
Em entrevista ao ge no mÃªs passado, o apresentador Milton Neves detalhou o golpe que teria sofrido do ex-funcionÃ¡rio . Na ocasiÃ£o, o apresentador disse que o valor era incalculÃ¡vel. Em outras entrevistas, ele chegou a mencionar que o prejuÃ­zo ultrapassava os R$ 17 milhÃµes.
"Tudo que aconteceu comigo ele queria ter tambÃ©m. Uma obsessÃ£o. E ele controlava o dinheiro, era muito dinheiro. Ele precisa ter esse puxÃ£o de orelha, porque me roubou demais. Foi a maior burrada que eu fiz na minha vida. Ã‰ incalculÃ¡vel [o valor perdido], porque ele roubava todo dia e ele tinha minhas senhas todas, porque ele era o 'bÃ£ozÃ£o'. Tinha muito dinheiro nesse banco, entÃ£o obedeciam a ele. Mas o ladrÃ£o, desesperado, o negÃ³cio dele, ele chegava lÃ¡ 'onde eu vou roubar hoje', uma coisa assim na cabeÃ§a dele, imagina. Roubou muito", disse o apresentador ao ge.
O g1 entrou em contato com a defesa do apresentador Milton Neves, mas atÃ© a Ãºltima atualizaÃ§Ã£o desta reportagem, ainda nÃ£o tinha recebido retorno.
O advogado Carlos Villalobos Cruz, que defende o ex-funcionÃ¡rio de Milton Neves, disse que a defesa irÃ¡ recorrer e que dispÃµe de provas robustas que vÃ£o ajudar a reverter a decisÃ£o.
"A defesa de Evandro CÃ©sar recebeu a noticia da condenaÃ§Ã£o em primeiro grau com tranquilidade, ainda hÃ¡ um longo caminho pela frente para se ter uma definiÃ§Ã£o, e temos a certeza que reverteremos esta decisÃ£o no Tribunal de SÃ£o Paulo", disse o advogado.

author: FC Barcelona
title: Bada Huesca 21-39 BarÃ§a: Resounding win
text:
Bada Huesca 21-39 BarÃ§a: Resounding win
- Viber
- Messenger
- Copy link
Another Liga Plenitude win for BarÃ§a as they defeated Bada Huesca 21-39 at the Palacio Municipal de Huesca for their 19th win of a league season that has only seen victories so far. Javier RodrÃ­guez top scored for the blaugranes with six, while Cikusa returned after six weeks out.
Difficult start
Both sides' attack was misfiring from the off so goals were a bit hard to come by, so much so that the score was only 5 - 4 halfway through the first half. Defences were on top, with goalkeepers Decsi and Nielsen making six and five saves respectively. However, Ortega's side showed just what they are made of and went into overdrive.
Blown away
The blaugranes scored 9 without reply through quick transitions and goals by BazÃ¡n, Janc, Nâ€™Guessan (3), Javier RodrÃ­guez (3) and Richardson, while Emil Nielsen made another five saves to make it 10 in 15 shots (5-13, min 24). That then paved way to a calm period in the game, halftime score 7-16.
More of the same
The home side attempted to come back after the restart (10-17, min 33), but BarÃ§a quickly hit back, this time led by Dika Mem, who scored three goals early on and the lead grew to 12-23 by the 40th minute.
Makuc and Aleix GÃ³mez also scored two and five respectively in the second half to extend the blaugrana control. Young Filip Saric replaced Nielsen in goal and put in another solid performance with six saves. Final score 21-39 and another win for the clear leaders of the Liga Plenitude.
Next up, Viveros Herol Nava visit the Palau Blaugrana for the Liga Plenitude gameweek 21 fixture (22 Mar 1.00pm CET).
GAME STATS
Bada Huesca 21
BarÃ§a 39
Bada Huesca: Decsi (-), Borragan FernÃ¡ndez (3), PÃ©rez (3), Paulo (6), Frank CordiÃ©s (1), Parera (1), Malo (2) -starting seven- Arguillas (-), CÃ¡novas (-), GarcÃ­a (1), De Souza (-), Moya (1), SuÃ¡rez (1), Nasarre (-), Nenadic (2), Samuel CordiÃ©s (-).
BarÃ§a: Nielsen (-), Janc (1), Mem (4), Petrus (-), BazÃ¡n (5), Palomino (1), Wanne (1) -starting seven- Saric (-), Carlsbogard (1), AriÃ±o (3), N'Guessan (3), Aleix GÃ³mez (5), Makuc (2), Richardson (4), Cikusa (3), RodrÃ­guez (6).
Periods: 2-1; 4-3; 5-5; 5-9; 6-14; 7-16 // 10-19; 12-23; 14-27; 17-30; 20-35; 21-39.
Referees: Lorena GarcÃ­a Gil and Tania RodrÃ­guez EstÃ©vez.

author: Christopher Correa
title: Stanislaus State to host Turlock Highâ€™s annual Godinez Tournament
text:
For the first time in the nearly five decades of the Frank Godinez Boys Basketball Tournament, varsity games will be played off the campus of Turlock High School.
The 48th edition of the popular winter tournament, sponsored by the Turlock Journal, will tip off Thursday night across town, at Stanislaus Stateâ€™s Fitzpatrick Arena. The university will host each varsity game of the three-day event, which features Turlock, Oakdale, Modesto, Grace Davis, Patterson, East Union, Johansen and Golden Valley.
Opening night of the tournament gets underway at 4 p.m. when Patterson takes on Modesto. At 5:30, Johansen and East Union will clash. The Bulldogs, under new head coach Rick Fetter, will begin their quest for their third tournament title in four years, and 13th overall, when they face Oakdale at 7. The night concludes with Davis and Golden Valley tipping off at 8:30.
The tournament, which usually takes place the second week of December, has also been pushed up a week after timing conflicts came about when the 2024-23 schedule was being constructed last year. Despite the move in dates, there remained a scheduling conflict, as the usual venue, Bulldog Arena, had already been booked to host the annual Bulldog Classic wrestling tournament, an event that requires mats to be put in place a full day before action on Saturday. Luckily, the Stanislaus State volleyball and basketball teams are all on the road this week, and the folks there were quick to welcome Turlock High with open arms.
Even with the varsity games moving to North Turlock, there remained a conflict with the junior varsity competitions. While those games will remain at Marchant Gymnasium for Thursday, Fridayâ€™s slate will take place at nearby Dutcher Middle School to avoid the heavy traffic and closed closures leading up to the annual Turlock Christmas Parade. Games will return to THS on Saturday.
Fetter, a longtime hoops coach for the programâ€™s junior varsity and freshman levels, took the reins for Doug Cornfoot this offseason. Cornfoot, one of the most celebrated coaches in school history, stepped away after last season following a one-year comeback from retirement.
The tournament is named after another local legend, Frank Godinez, a longtime sports reporter for the Journal. He was nicknamed Mr. Bulldog, as he was known to be on the sidelines for most Turlock Highâ€™s sporting events.

author: A.L.
title: Feria de empleo ofrece 450 puestos de trabajo: quiÃ©nes pueden acceder y cÃ³mo anotarse
text:
Feria de empleo ofrece 450 puestos de trabajo: quiÃ©nes pueden acceder y cÃ³mo anotarse
Quienes buscan empleo, tendrÃ¡n la posibilidad de presentarse a mÃ¡s de 450 puestos de trabajo en la prÃ³xima Expo Empleo Barrial. La oportunidad serÃ¡ para los vecinos de Chacarita, Villa Crespo, La Paternal, Villa OrtÃºzar, AgronomÃ­a y Parque Chas, el prÃ³ximo martes 12 de agosto, de 10 a 15, en la sede de la Comuna 15, ubicada en Chacarita.
Organizada por el Ministerio de Justicia de la Ciudad, a travÃ©s de la SecretarÃ­a de Trabajo y Empleo, la iniciativa reunirÃ¡ a 30 empresas de diversos rubros y organismos pÃºblicos que recibirÃ¡n postulaciones de personas de todas las edades. La propuesta incluye entrevistas laborales, charlas y talleres gratuitos para mejorar las posibilidades de inserciÃ³n laboral.
Las empresas que forman parte de esta ediciÃ³n de Expo Empleo Barrial, son: Grupo Medihome, Grupo Efes, Grupo Jaka, Cat Technologies, Limpianor, Proyecto GastronÃ³mico Andino, Il Quotidiano, Simplia Facilities, RES, Gennera, Magoya, Universal Traslados, Grupo L, CafÃ© MartÃ­nez, MÃ¡s Activos, Burger King, Chungo, Randstad, Prosegur, Auren, Muntaner RRHH, CorporixHR, Mostaza, Grupo Abans, Lauritsen Marcas y Patentes, Famiq, NH hotels & Resorts, Grupo Premedic y Deheza.
La ediciÃ³n de agosto serÃ¡ la octava jornada de intermediaciÃ³n laboral del aÃ±o. En lo que va de 2025, la Expo ya pasÃ³ por Caballito, Balvanera, La Rural â€”con mÃ¡s de 1.700 propuestasâ€” y Boedo, entre otros puntos de la Ciudad.
Feria de empleo: cÃ³mo pueden anotarse
Quienes quieran sumarse deben completar un formulario de preinscripciÃ³n antes del lunes 11 de agosto. Los perfiles serÃ¡n evaluados y, en caso de ajustarse a los puestos disponibles, recibirÃ¡n una citaciÃ³n por correo electrÃ³nico o WhatsApp, generando asÃ­ oportunidades concretas y favorables para ambas partes.
Hay tiempo para pre inscribirse hasta el lunes 11 de agosto y deberÃ¡n hacerlo a travÃ©s del link de la pÃ¡gina del Gobierno de la Ciudad de Buenos Aires.
Oferta de empleo: los puestos de trabajo a los que se puede acceder
Las vacantes a cubrir informadas son para personas mayores de 45 aÃ±os:
- chef,
- ayudante de cocina,
- peÃ³n de cocina,
- camareros/as,
- bacheros/as,
- cocineros/as,
- aprendiz de carnicerÃ­a,
- cajeros/as,
- especialista en producto multidestino,
- pago a proveedores,
- analista contable,
- responsable de comunicaciÃ³n y marketing,
- administrativo/a,
- diseÃ±ador/a UX/UI,
- backend,
- data engineer,
- frontend,
- conductor/a bilingÃ¼e inglÃ©s,
- atenciÃ³n al cliente call center,
- analista de atenciÃ³n a conductores (RRHH),
- ejecutivo/a comercial,
- ayudantes y oficiales albaÃ±iles,
- mantenimiento edilicio,
- oficial de primera,
- operadores/as telefÃ³nicos/as,
- crew,
- analista de impuestos SR,
- asesor/a comercial,
- analista de facturaciÃ³n SR,
- vigilador,
- empleado/a polivalente,
- armadores/as de pedidos,
- operario/a de depÃ³sito,
- armadores/as de PC,
- tÃ©cnico/a de mantenimiento, entre otros.
La jornada tambiÃ©n contarÃ¡ con un cronograma de actividades en tres auditorios. Entre ellas, se dictarÃ¡n capacitaciones sobre habilidades blandas, gestiÃ³n emocional, estrategias para entrevistas, uso de LinkedIn, orientaciÃ³n vocacional y bÃºsqueda laboral 360Â°. AdemÃ¡s, habrÃ¡ propuestas mÃ¡s especÃ­ficas como introducciÃ³n a la coctelerÃ­a o entrevistas grupales con empresas.
La Expo Empleo Barrial es una iniciativa que la SecretarÃ­a de Trabajo y Empleo de la Ciudad desarrolla desde 2017, priorizando las comunas con mayores Ã­ndices de vulnerabilidad laboral y social. Su objetivo es acercar a los vecinos oportunidades concretas sin que tengan que trasladarse lejos de su barrio, generando un vÃ­nculo directo entre candidatos y empleadores.
La fuerza laboral total en Argentina se estima en 22.285.744 personas y hay 1,45 millones de desocupados, de los que casi un tercio llevan mÃ¡s de un aÃ±o buscando trabajo.
En detalle, un 27,6% de las personas que estÃ¡n activamente buscando un empleo se pasaron mÃ¡s de 12 meses dejando currÃ­culums.

author: Hannah Levitan, Josie Abugov
title: Christmas tree recycling starts in New Orleans metro | Environment | nola.com
text:
Close Louisiana Army National Guards helicopters drop Christmas trees into the Madere Marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Refuge on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The City's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dropped about 8,000 trees which was a 100% increase from last year. Over the 26 years of this program, recycled trees have restored approximately 200 football fields worth of marsh. (Photo by Chris Granger, The Times-Picayune)
(Photo by Chris Granger The Times-Picayune) Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Louisiana Army National Guard helicopters airlift Christmas trees to the Madere Marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Refuge on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The City's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dropped about 8,000 trees which was a 100% increase from last year. Over the 26 years of this program, recycled trees have restored approximately 200 football fields worth of marsh. (Photo by Chris Granger, The Times-Picayune)
(Photo by Chris Granger The Times-Picayune) Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Crews move bundles of Christmas trees in the Madere Marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Refuge on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The City's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dropped about 8,000 trees which was a 100% increase from last year. Over the 26 years of this program, recycled trees have restored approximately 200 football fields worth of marsh. (Photo by Chris Granger, The Times-Picayune)
(Photo by Chris Granger The Times-Picayune) Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save Recycled Christmas trees are building up the coast near New Orleans. Here's how to join in. BY HANNAH LEVITAN and JOSIE ABUGOV | Staff writers Dec 26, 2024 33 mins ago 3 min to read Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Louisiana Army National Guards helicopters drop Christmas trees into the Madere Marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Refuge on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The City's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dropped about 8,000 trees which was a 100% increase from last year. Over the 26 years of this program, recycled trees have restored approximately 200 football fields worth of marsh. (Photo by Chris Granger, The Times-Picayune)
(Photo by Chris Granger The Times-Picayune) Louisiana Army National Guard helicopters airlift Christmas trees to the Madere Marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Refuge on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The City's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dropped about 8,000 trees which was a 100% increase from last year. Over the 26 years of this program, recycled trees have restored approximately 200 football fields worth of marsh. (Photo by Chris Granger, The Times-Picayune)
(Photo by Chris Granger The Times-Picayune) Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save After the wrapping paper is picked up, the tinsel is vacuumed and all that's left is the tree, finding a place to dispose of your fir can be daunting. Thankfully, several parishes in the New Orleans metro area have a quick system designed to pick up the discarded trees and use them to fight coastal erosion.
Christmas tree recycling programs have existed for decades in the area. After residents return their trees to their parish, experts determine where to place them to help protect the coast while minimizing tree-induced hazards.
By sifting sediment flowing in the water, the tree's roots help collect enough of it to form new land, once the sediment settles and the roots firm up.
How it started The initiative began in the 1980s amid a national movement to recycle Christmas trees. Local government leaders, as well as LSU scientists and environmental groups such as the Coalition to Restore Coastal Louisiana (CRCL), sought to repurpose old firs that would have otherwise gone to landfills.
An LSU graduate student from the Netherlands, Roelef Boumans, first introduced the idea , which had long been used in his home country.
The eventual success of the program led more than a dozen coastal parishes to adopt their own tree recycling efforts.
This will be the 35th year that Jefferson Parish will collect firs. Michelle Gonzales, Jefferson Parish's director of ecosystems and coastal management, said the project has since helped establish over 1,300 feet of fences that help absorb and soften waves, thus reducing erosion.
Now, over 2,000 feet of shoreline is protected from daily wave action by the fences. Gonzales said the program has directly impacted more than 20 acres in the Barataria Basin.
For the past five years, the program has collected between 2,000 to 4,000 trees each year, according to Gonzales.
Orleans Parish has had its own Christmas tree recycling program for the last 26 years, contributing to the restoration of 200 football fields-worth of marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Wildlife Refuge in New Orleans East.
Crews move bundles of Christmas trees in the Madere Marsh in the Bayou Sauvage Urban National Refuge on Wednesday, March 20, 2024. The City's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, in partnership with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service, dropped about 8,000 trees which was a 100% increase from last year. Over the 26 years of this program, recycled trees have restored approximately 200 football fields worth of marsh. (Photo by Chris Granger, The Times-Picayune)
(Photo by Chris Granger The Times-Picayune) In addition to storm and erosion protection, the trees also create habitat for crabs, crawfish, birds, shrimp and fish.
"I feel like so often when we talk about coastal restoration, you just hear the statistics and all you can do is be aware and be bummed out," Cheryn Robles, environmental administrator for the city's Office of Resilience and Sustainability, said. "This is an opportunity to be engaged."
This year, Orleans Parish is aiming to collect 8,000 trees, the same figure as last year. Hitting the mark could be more difficult, however, because most of the Christmas trees come to the area from North Carolina, where damage from Hurricane Helene led to fewer trees and cost increases.
"It was just harder to get trees this year," Robles said.
For the first time this year, the parish began collecting trees on Dec. 26. Usually, recycling begins on Jan. 6, the day of Epiphany. Residents can call 311 to get curbside tree pickup for the first 400 trees. In collaborating with the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service and the Louisiana Army National Guard, Robles said the program is aiming to drop the trees sometime in March, around Earth Day.
In a related project not open to the public, CRCL recycled wreaths last year in partnership with the National Society of the Daughters of the American Revolution, which had placed 1,300 wreaths at Chalmette National Cemetery.
The coastal group then worked with students at the University of New Orleans to string the wreaths together and anchor them to the floor of Quarantine Bay in Plaquemines Parish, to encourage sediment build up. CRCL plans to continue the project this season, with over 3,000 wreaths.
Other places around the country also use Christmas trees for various restoration initiatives. In Wisconsin, the firs are placed in lakes to improve fish habitats. Ohio also uses trees to halt erosion by dropping them in stream banks. Some areas, like Massachusetts, use the trees to build beach dunes.
How to recycle your tree Orleans Parish
From Dec. 26 through Jan. 3, you can call 311 to request curbside pickup.
For scheduled pickup, place your trees on the curb by 5 a.m. Jan. 6 through Jan. 10.
You can also drop off your trees from Dec. 26 to Jan. 5 at 2930 Lafitte Ave. or Bodenger Park, 3400 Kansas St.
Residents in the French Quarter and Downtown Development District should place their trees on the curb by 4 a.m. on Jan. 9.
Jefferson Parish
You can either place your tree on the curb outside your home on Jan. 8, or bring it to a drop-off site.
Curb pick-up will occur Jan. 9 through Jan. 11.
If you want to cherish your tree for a bit longer, you can drop it off at 400 David Drive, Metairie or 6440 Lapalco Boulevard, Marrero from Jan. 4 through Jan. 14.
The Jefferson Parish Christmas tree recycling drop event will take place on January 25 from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. behind Cochiara's Marina in Lafitte. Volunteers under 18 can sign up here and adults can sign up here .
St. Tammany Parish
St. Tammany typically runs a tree-recycling program. Details for this year have not yet been released. Stay tuned for updates.
St. Charles Parish
Starting Dec. 30, residents can drop off their trees at the Ormond Sandbag Location (next to 1901 Ormond Blvd in Destrehan), and The West Bank Bridge Park in Luling until Jan. 16.
Trees can also be placed curbside from Jan. 13 to Jan. 17 for collection.
To recycle your tree, make sure it meets the following guidelines:
No flocked trees No artificial trees No painted trees No lights, garland, tinsel, ornaments, tree stands or plastic bags Facebook Twitter WhatsApp SMS Email Print Copy article link Save

author: @CTVVancouver
title: Dog found starving in B.C. forest gets adopted | CTV News
text: A dog that was found emaciated in B.C.â€™s North Okanagan last summer has found a forever home, the BC SPCA announced. The nine-year-old Labrador retriever mix was taken to a shelter in Shuswap by a Good Samaritan after he wandered out of the woods outside Enderby, B.C. in July. Named Fish by staff, the dog was â€œskin and bones and covered in sores,â€ when he arrived at the BC SPCA centre. He needed a supervised feeding program to help him gain weight and muscle mass, as well as dental surgery to remove infected and broken teeth. â€œFortunately, the sores on his body healed once he had a soft bed to sleep on,â€ the charity wrote. After months of treatment, the malnourished dog fully recovered and went up for adoption. Fishâ€™s new family took him home just before the holidays, according to the BC SPCA. His forever home is with Tony and Darlene, a retired couple who were looking for a rescue they could â€œshower with loveâ€ after they lost their dog Abby in July. â€œWe read a story about Fish and we just knew he was our dog,â€ said Tony in a Friday media release. â€œWe couldnâ€™t be happier for Fish,â€ said Isabell Diederichs, assistant manager of the BC SPCAâ€™s Shuswap shelter, in the release. â€œHe is the most loving dog who deserves the best home and he has that now.â€ After they picked Fish up at the shelter, Tony said â€œwe opened the door to our truck he jumped right in. He didnâ€™t hesitate at all.â€ The couple has taken in a number of rescues over the years, but no dog settled in as quickly as Fish, Darlene said. â€œConsidering everything he has been through, his trust in people is just amazing,â€ she said. â€œHe is just so loving and big-hearted.â€ Fish has found a new friend in Ballou, the coupleâ€™s rescue cat. The pair now enjoy taking naps together on the couch. Fish and Ballou together on the couch. (BC SPCA) â€œThey got along right from the get-go,â€ Darlene said. â€œFish was so calm and gentle around him.â€ â€œBallou was missing Abby terribly. He loves to spend time with Fish and is excited to see him when he gets back from his walks,â€ Tony added. Speaking of walks, Fish is very enthusiastic about them. â€œWhen he knows it is time for a walk Fish will pick up your boots or shoes for you to help speed up the process or he will carry his leash,â€ Tony said. â€œWe have an amazing dog beach right by the lake that he loves. He has been so good with other dogs and just loves meeting new people,â€ he continued. After being found starving and wounded, Fish now gets all the love and attention he needs. â€œWe just want to make Fish the happiest dog we can,â€ said Darlene. â€œWe are retired, so there is always someone at home with him. Whatever he needs, he gets.â€ â€œHe rescued me,â€ Tony added. Shopping Trends The Shopping Trends team is independent of the journalists at CTV News. We may earn a commission when you use our links to shop. Read about us. Elephant populations are stable, but more connected protected areas are needed for long-term sustainability: study The number of African savannah elephants is no longer dwindling on the continent, but in order to achieve long-term stability itâ€™s important to establish more connected protected areas, according to a new study. Atlantic - Moncton hockey community holds moment of silence for five-year-old who died Tuesday Before the puck dropped at a Saturday morning hockey game in Moncton, people held a moment of silence for Tate Hughes, a five-year-old who died suddenly on Tuesday. - Sydney, N.S., Highland Arts Theatre marks ten-year anniversary The Highland Arts Theatre in Sydney, N.S., is celebrating the ten-year anniversary since it was converted from a church. - Fire destroys well-known Cap-PelÃ©, N.B., restaurant and fish market A fire in Cap-PelÃ©, N.B., Sunday morning has destroyed a well-known seaside restaurant and fish market. Two 23-year-olds from Ottawa are facing a variety of charges â€“ including drug trafficking and weapon offences â€“ following incidents last week in the Town of Echo Bay, Ont. - Extreme cold alert issued in Sudbury Organizations in Greater Sudbury that deal with people experiencing homelessness are issuing an extreme cold alert Sunday. - Big expectations for Sudbury in 2024 as far as film is concerned Hollywood strikes have been solved and industry experts say itâ€™s full-steam ahead for Sudbury and northern Ontario filming in 2024. title: Ground News - The power of love, panel agrees, is imperative for moral authority
text:
Summary by Daily Maverick Key outcomes of a panel discussion at The Gathering were that it takes love to address injustice, and intersectional approaches between state, business and civic society are key to maintaining moral authority.
